(a) $\Pr(X=Y) = \frac{1}{n}$

(b) $\Pr(X \lt Y) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{1 \le i \le n}{(n-i})$

(c) $\Pr(X \gt Y) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{1 \le i \le n}{(n-i)}$
(d) Let $U = \max(X,Y)$. Then $\Pr(U = k) = \Pr(U \le k) - \Pr(U \le k-1)$. $\Pr(U \le k) = \left(\frac{k}{n}\right)^2$, so $\Pr(U = k) = \frac{k^2-(k-1)^2}{n^2}$
(e) Similarly, let $V = \min(X,Y)$. Then $\Pr(V = k) = \Pr(V \ge k) - \Pr(V \ge k+1)$.
$\Pr(V \ge k) = \left(\frac{n-k+1}{n}\right)^2$, so $\Pr(V = k) = \frac{(n-k+1)^2 - (n-k)^2}{n^2}$.

(a) Let $E$ denote the event that an even number was drawn with probability $e$. Similarly, let $O$ be the event that an odd number was drawn with probability $o=1-e$. Note that $\Pr(X + Y\text{ is even}) = \Pr(EE + OO) = 2e^2 - 2e + 1 \ge \frac{1}{2}$, since when $\frac{\text{d}P}{\text{d}x} = 4e-2 = 0$, then $e = \frac{1}{2}$, and thus the minimum is $\Pr(EE + OO \mid e = \frac{1}{2}) = \frac{1}{2}$
